summary: This document contains the official autopsy report and toxicology report for Jeffrey Edward Epstein from the New York City Office of Chief Medical Examiner. The autopsy was performed on August 11, 2019, and the cause of death is listed as hanging, with the manner of death ruled as suicide. The toxicology report shows no drugs or alcohol were detected in his system. This document is a collection of reports from the NYC Office of the Chief Medical Examiner related to the autopsy and death investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. It includes toxicology results (negative for synthetic cannabinoids), neuropathology findings (normal brain), anthropology findings (fractures to hyoid and thyroid cartilage), and a detailed investigation report describing the scene and circumstances of his death in the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). These are internal case notes from the New York City Office of the Chief Medical Examiner documenting the death investigation of Jeffrey Epstein. The notes detail the autopsy process, evidence collection, communication with Epstein's family attorney and brother, and coordination with the FBI and NYPD. They reveal the family's request for a private pathologist to observe the autopsy and the medical examiner's communication about amending the death certificate. This document contains the official Notice of Death for Jeffrey Epstein, mortuary release paperwork, and an FBI interview summary with an MCC Lieutenant regarding the circumstances of Epstein's death. It details the discovery of Epstein unresponsive in his cell, the response, and reveals potential policy violations regarding inmate checks and cellmate requirements. This document is a compilation of Bureau of Prisons records detailing Jeffrey Epstein's self-mutilation incident in July 2019 and his subsequent death by suicide in August 2019 at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It includes incident reports, a detailed timeline of the suicide and response, memoranda from staff, chain of custody logs for evidence recovered from his cell, and administrative worksheets related to the crime scene investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The 66-year-old male inmate found dead in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) on August 10, 2019. The subject of the autopsy and death investigation.

persons.name: Barbara A. Sampson
persons.context: Chief Medical Examiner for the NYC Office of Chief Medical Examiner, whose name appears on official reports and forms.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein's brother and next of kin. He was contacted regarding the autopsy, had no objection but requested a private pathologist observer, and was involved in a detailed phone discussion about the cause and manner of death.

persons.name: Michael Thomas
persons.context: The officer who found Jeffrey Epstein hanging in his cell #220 at 06:33 hours on August 10, 2019, and removed him.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate in July 2019 who witnessed and reported Epstein's prior suicide attempt by hanging on July 23, 2019.

persons.name: Reyes
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate in cell #220 who was released from court on the morning of August 9, 2019, leaving Epstein alone in the cell.

persons.name: Stacey Richman
persons.context: Attorney for Jeffrey Epstein's family. The medical examiner attempted to contact her to finalize the autopsy report and later spoke with her and Mark Epstein about the cause and manner of death.

persons.name: Dr. S
persons.context: A privately retained pathologist who accompanied Mark Epstein to observe Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy. He was swabbed for DNA before the observation.

persons.name: VCS Coleman
persons.context: FBI Multimedia Exploitation Unit specialist who showed medical examiner investigators video footage from the Metropolitan Correctional Center related to Epstein's death timeframe.

persons.name: James Saunders
persons.context: An attorney from the FDNY Bureau of Legal Affairs who provided medical records requested for the death investigation.

persons.name: Dr. NB
persons.context: A physician at New York Presbyterian Lower Manhattan Hospital with whom the medical examiner discussed the case.

persons.name: Lt.
persons.context: Interviewed by the FBI on August 12, 2019; described the hierarchy at MCC, procedures, and his actions upon discovering Epstein unresponsive in his cell. He reported that officers admitted to not conducting required rounds.

persons.name: Mr.
persons.context: An official at the Metropolitan Correctional Center whose office the medical examiner's calls were transferred to.

persons.name: Geraldine
persons.context: A representative from 'Uve On NY' who requested a media hold on the case, which was denied due to its high-profile nature.

persons.name: Stephen Schubert
persons.context: Representing Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel; received Epstein's body from the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner on August 11, 2019.

persons.name: Epstein, Mark
persons.context: Named as the person who authorized Stephen Schubert to remove Jeffrey Epstein's body; appears to be a family member.

persons.name: Shirley Canty
persons.context: Recorded the initial call regarding Epstein's death at MCC prison as a possible hanging.

persons.name: Officer
persons.context: The other CO present in Epstein's cell; told Lt. 'EPSTEIN hung himself' and later admitted to not conducting the 3am and 5am rounds.

persons.name: Lieutenant G.
persons.context: Assumed duties as the Morning Watch Operations Lieutenant at 12:00 AM on August 10, 2019, as recorded in the Daily Lieutenant's Log.

persons.name: Fernandez
persons.context: An inmate (Reg #86824-054) noted as being in a dry cell with staff watch in the MCC logs.

persons.name: Mutimura
persons.context: An inmate (Reg #76329-054) noted in the MCC log on August 9, 2019.

persons.name: Carreon-Macias
persons.context: An inmate (Reg #82858-198) released on bail bond on August 9, 2019, per the MCC log.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure of the document; details his self-mutilation attempt on July 23, 2019, and his death by suicide on August 10, 2019, while incarcerated at MCC New York.

persons.name: Reyes Efrain
persons.context: Listed as Epstein's cellmate who departed for court on the morning of August 9, 2019, the day before Epstein's death.

persons.name: Judge Berman
persons.context: U.S. District Judge presiding over Epstein's case; notified of his death on the morning of August 10, 2019.

persons.name: Director Wiggins
persons.role: Director, Office of Chief Medical Examiner (OCME)
persons.context: Coordinated with the Institution Duty Officer (IDO) regarding the transport of Epstein's remains to the city morgue.

connections.description: Mark Epstein is identified as the brother of Jeffrey Epstein and acted as the next of kin for identification and autopsy decisions.
Were cellmates in July 2019; Tartaglione witnessed Epstein's prior suicide attempt.
Were cellmates in cell #220 in the SHU until Reyes was released on August 9, 2019.
Officer Thomas discovered Epstein hanging in his cell and initiated the response.
Stacey Richman is identified as the family's attorney. She facilitated communication between the medical examiner and Mark Epstein regarding the cause and manner of death.
Stacey Richman is identified as the attorney for Jeffrey Epstein's family in matters related to his death investigation.
Dr. S, a private pathologist, was retained by or for Mark Epstein to observe Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy. He accompanied Mark Epstein to the medical examiner's office.
VCS Coleman of the FBI showed video footage from the MCC to medical examiner investigators as part of the death investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.
Lt., a GS-11 Lieutenant, supervised Officer, a Corrections Officer, at MCC. He directed her during the medical emergency and later advised her on reporting the incident.
Both were GS-11 Lieutenants at MCC. Lt. relieved Lt. of duty at approximately 5:30am on August 10, 2019.
Both were Corrections Officers on duty in the SHU when Epstein was found. They were together in Epstein's cell attempting to respond to the emergency.
Schubert, a funeral director, certified that he had been authorized by Mark Epstein to take charge of Jeffrey Epstein's body.
Were cellmates in SHU cell 124 at MCC New York; Tartaglione alerted staff to Epstein's self-mutilation attempt.
Listed as cellmates; Reyes departed for court on August 9, 2019.
Judge Berman was the presiding judge in Epstein's case and was formally notified of his death.

events.title: Autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Autopsy performed on Jeffrey Edward Epstein at the Manhattan Mortuary of the Office of Chief Medical Examiner, commencing at 9:21 AM.

events.title: Certification of Autopsy Records
events.description: A Clerical Associate IV certifies and authenticates the autopsy records as true and correct copies of the original records.

events.title: Prior suicide attempt by Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein attempted suicide by hanging in his cell using a torn orange bedsheet. He was found by cellmate Tartaglione and transferred to Suicide Watch.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found hanging by the neck in his cell (#220) at the MCC at 06:33 hours by Officer Michael Thomas. He was pronounced dead at New York Presbyterian Lower Manhattan Hospital at 07:36 hours despite resuscitative efforts.

events.title: Autopsy performed
events.description: An autopsy was performed on Jeffrey Epstein's body at the NYC OCME, with the family's independent forensic pathologist observing as a courtesy.

events.title: Toxicology report finalized
events.description: NMS Laboratories finalized the toxicology report (Workorder 19244749) showing no positive findings of toxicological significance for synthetic cannabinoids in femoral blood.

events.title: Review of MCC Surveillance Video
events.description: Medical examiner investigators and an FBI video specialist review blurry surveillance footage from the MCC covering the timeframe around Epstein's death. The footage did not show Epstein's cell.

events.title: Discussion on Cause and Manner of Death
events.description: The medical examiner holds a long, detailed phone conversation with Mark Epstein and his attorney Stacey Richman to discuss the determination of cause and manner of death before amending the death certificate.

events.title: Prior Suicide Attempt
events.description: Referenced in documents received from MCC, focusing on a prior suicide attempt incident involving Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Medical Emergency Response at MCC
events.description: A medical emergency was announced for inmate Epstein. Lt. responded, found two COs with Epstein, continued CPR, called for an AED and the Duty Nurse. EMS arrived and transported Epstein to the hospital.

events.title: Admission of Missed Rounds
events.description: Officer stated to Lt. 'we didn't do rounds at 3am and 5am' and admitted to falsifying count slips if they were signed, indicating a serious breach of protocol.

events.title: Mortuary Release of Epstein's Body
events.description: Funeral director Stephen Schubert received Epstein's body from the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner at 18:11, authorized by Mark Epstein.

events.title: FBI Interview of MCC Lieutenant
events.description: Lt. was interviewed by FBI Special Agents, an OIG Special Agent, and an AUSA regarding Epstein's death, MCC procedures, and the events of August 9-10, 2019.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was first placed on suicide watch on this date, as noted by Lt. during his interview.

events.title: Epstein Self-Mutilation Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein attempted to hang himself with an orange homemade rope in his SHU cell (124) at MCC New York. He was found by staff, breathing but unresponsive, and removed from the cell.

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive and Death
events.description: At approximately 6:33 AM, a body alarm was activated in the SHU. Staff found Epstein unresponsive in his cell. CPR was initiated, EMS transported him to Beekman Hospital, and he was pronounced dead at 7:36 AM by an ER physician.

events.title: Epstein's Last Social Call
events.description: In the evening, Epstein was provided a social call. He stated he was calling his mother. The call was ended after 15 minutes. The IDO reported Epstein was in 'good spirits' with 'nothing unusual'.

events.title: Notification and Investigation Initiation
events.description: Following Epstein's death, multiple agencies were notified including the USMS, FBI, AUSA, OIG, and Judge Berman. The FBI and OIG arrived at MCC to investigate. Evidence from Epstein's cell was collected and logged.

events.title: Evidence Collection from Cell
events.description: Staff recovered personal items and potential evidence from Epstein's cell (location 9 South 206-220-LAD), including medications, a bible, mail, an 'orange material', and a piece of brown paper bag with writing.

keyFacts: The official cause of death for Jeffrey Epstein is listed as HANGING, with the manner of death ruled as SUICIDE (Hanged Self).
The autopsy report details a ligature furrow on the neck, fractures of the thyroid cartilage and hyoid bone, and petechial hemorrhages consistent with hanging.

Toxicology reports on femoral blood, vitreous fluid, and other specimens found no ethanol, benzoylecgonine, barbiturates, opiates, amphetamines, benzodiazepines, cannabinoids, fentanyl, gabapentin, pregabalin, or other basic drugs.
The body showed injuries consistent with resuscitation attempts, including anterior parasternal rib fractures and a hepatic laceration.
The autopsy was performed on August 11, 2019, and the report was electronically signed by the medical examiner on August 27, 2019.
The autopsy and investigation reports detail the discovery of Jeffrey Epstein hanging in his cell (#220) at the MCC on the morning of August 10, 2019.
Forensic anthropology analysis revealed fractures to the left greater horn of the hyoid bone and both superior horns of the thyroid cartilage.
Toxicology testing on femoral blood for synthetic cannabinoids returned negative results, with no positive findings of toxicological significance.
Epstein had a prior suicide attempt by hanging on July 23, 2019, witnessed by his then-cellmate Tartaglione.
Epstein's brother, Mark Epstein, requested and was granted permission for an independent forensic pathologist to observe the official autopsy.
Jeffrey Epstein's brother, Mark Epstein, requested and was granted permission for a privately retained pathologist (Dr. S) to observe the autopsy.
The medical examiner had a detailed phone call with Mark Epstein and attorney Stacey Richman on August 18, 2019, to discuss the cause and manner of death before amending the death certificate.
FBI video footage reviewed from the MCC on August 16 was blurry, did not show Epstein's cell, and made individuals indiscernible.
The case was designated as 'High Profile,' leading the medical examiner to deny a media hold request from a news outlet.
The notes document multiple failed attempts by the medical examiner to reach specific officials at the MCC by phone immediately following Epstein's death.
Jeffrey Epstein was pronounced dead at New York Presbyterian Lower Manhattan Hospital on August 10, 2019, at 7:36 AM after being found unresponsive in his MCC cell.
An MCC Corrections Officer admitted to Lt. that required 3am and 5am inmate count rounds were not conducted on the night of Epstein's death, suggesting falsified logs.
Lt. stated that MCC policy required all inmates, including those on suicide watch or psychological observation, to have a cellmate ('bunkie'), but Epstein did not have one at the time of his death.
The official Notice of Death lists Epstein's marital status as 'Never Married' and the manner of death as 'Undetermined'.
The FBI interview reveals potential systemic failures: missed rounds, lack of a cellmate contrary to policy, and distraught officers who left before writing required memos.
Jeffrey Epstein attempted suicide by hanging in his MCC cell on July 23, 2019, using an 'orange homemade rope'.
Epstein died by suicide on August 10, 2019. He was found unresponsive in his SHU cell at approximately 6:33 AM and pronounced dead at a hospital at 7:36 AM.
On the evening before his death (August 9), Epstein made a social call, reportedly to his mother, and was described by staff as being in 'good spirits' with 'nothing unusual'.
Immediately after his death, a multi-agency response was initiated involving the FBI, OIG, USMS, and the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner.
Evidence recovered from Epstein's cell after his death included an 'orange material', personal medications, a bible, mail, and a brown paper bag with the writing 'SW U2 dinner'.
